comments: Root *h1ed- ‘bite (> eat)’, Arm. erkn, ‘labour pains’, Gr. /04 ‘pain’ and OIr. idu ‘pain’. Kortlandt (1989:50) convincingly argues that these latter three words cannot be cognate to one another (Arm. erkn belongs with erk ‘toil’ ~ OHG furhten (Kortlandt 1976: 98), Gr. /04 reflects *h3ed- and OIr. idu ~ Goth. fita ‘to have labour pains’) and that therefore the reconstruction of a noun *h1edun ‘pain’ is unfounded. Rasmussen (1984: 144-57, taken over by Adams 1999:513) connects TochB yolo ‘bad, evil’ with the Anatolian forms.

semantic derivation: get swallen → be angry
IE_cognates: Norv. svella to swell, Eng. swell. Lat. īnsolēscō
hitt: šulle-; šullai-,  šullēzi ‘to be arrogant’; šullatar, šullann- (n.) with the meaning; ‘a swelling state’ (in figurative meaning), ‘unjustifiable arrogance’ (:)šallakartae-
comments: Molina: Indo-European correspondences include Norv. svella ‘to swell’, Eng. swell with the same meaning, and Lat. īnsolēscō ‘to become arrogant’, on the basis of which (EDHIL 778f) reconstructs a Proto-Indo-European suffixal form *sulH-eh1-. According to Melchert (2004), the development of an emotional meaning here is comparatively late, since remnants of the meaning 'swollen' can already be traced in Hittite (i.e. the trilingual KUB 4.4 obv. 2–9). The same semantical transition to the meaning of arrogance in Latin, therefore, is a parallel process. Melchert PIE *suelH- ‘to swell’.

semantic derivation: drop → humidity → steam → smell → pleasant smell → pleasant → soothing
IE_cognates: Skt. varṣá- ‘rain, Gr. ἐέρση ‘dew’
hitt: (GK) arsulai-; a similar verb *waršulāi-zi ‘appease’ (or sim.); waršula- ‘drop, humidity’, which is also attested with a secondary meaning ‘pleasant (appeasing) aroma’; warsiya- to appease (успокаивать); warsul- “calming” from wars(iya)- “to be satisfied”; a denominative warsulai- “to satisfy, set at ease”; waršiyatar (c.) ‘reconciliation(?)’: warša- (c.) ‘fog, mist’:
comments: Kloekhorst: comparison with Skt. varṣá- ‘rain’ and Gr. ἐέρση ‘dew’; PIE *h1u̯érs-s, *h1u̯érs-m, *h1u̯rs-ós; Tischler (HEG W): warsula- c. (hardly also warsul- n., l-stem) “drop; moisture, sweat,” and then the corresponding smell, namely on the one hand “(pleasant, sweet, anger-soothing) fragrance,” on the other hand “stench.” In HW (274), Friedrich translates this word as “Besänftigung, Beruhigung” and “Erfrischung” but adjusts this to “Tropfen; Saft; Duft” in HW Erg. 3: 36 (on the basis of Laroche 1963: 61), stating that, when used with eku-zi ‘to drink’, aršuli means “(im Tropfen), tropfenweise”. Güterbock (1986: 212) proposes to translate aršula- as ‘smell’, and states that “arsuli ekuzi should be translated “he drinks in the smell” and refers to “drinking the god” only by sniffing the aroma of the wine”. This translation, ‘smell, odor’, is taken over in CHD (e.g. the third context cited here is translated in CHD Š: 176 as ‘let the fragrant odor, (namely) the cedar and the oil summon you’). This works also fine for e.g.

IE etymology talks about semantics of "alone, without" --> to single out, set apart, isolate. D.S.: ‘excellent’ < ‘outstanding’ < ‘standing apart'/ Phonologically, especially Gk. ἄτερ ‘without’ speaks in favor of an aniṭ base *sen(‑), while PAnat. *sn̥‑nÉ‑H‑/*sn̥‑n‑H‑´ ‘to hide, conceal’ requires a laryngeal. There are various ways to explain the shape of this verb: it is either a factitive nasal present built on an adverb *sen‑h1 ‘apart’, [+] viz. *sn̥-nó-h1‑/*sn̥‑n‑h1- ‘to make apart’ [+] or, according to LIPP II:714, it has to be interpreted as a “praesens departiculativum”, viz. *sń̥h2o- derived from the univerbation *sn̥=h2o “(auch) ohne” ← *sen ‘apart’ + 2.*=h2o ‘also; and’ (LIPP II:334–345). [+] Although the problems regarding the phonological reconstruction of PAnat. *sn̥‑nÉ‑H‑/*sn̥‑n‑H‑´ ‘to hide, conceal’ cannot be solved yet, the underlying basis is reconstructable as a local adverb PIE *sen ‘apart’. [+]

semantic derivation: to desire → to ask for → to receive → consent, favour
IE_cognates: Goth. niutan 'catch, gain', nuta 'fisher', un-nuts 'useless', ON njōta 'use, enjoy', Lith. naudá 'gain, profit', borrowed Finnish nauttia 'enjoy' (cf. German Nutzniessung 'usufruct, profit', OIr. Nuadu < *Newd-ont- 'Fisher'). Alternative etyma might be Ved. návate 'bellow, bray, shout; exult, acclaim, praise', Toch. AB nu- 'shout' (Neumann, apud Tischler, Glossar L-M-N 354]), or Gk. νεύω, Lat. nuō 'nod, assent'
comments: Puhvel (HED N:131-132): an inner-Hittite cognate may be nuzzi- in lahhu(wa)r-nuzzi- 'leaf crop, foliage supply' (vel sim.), tying in with *new-d- 'catch, gain, enjoy' (IEW 768), seen in Goth. niutan 'catch, gain', nuta 'fisher', un-nuts 'useless', ON njōta 'use, enjoy', Lith. naudá 'gain, profit', borrowed Finnish nauttia 'enjoy' (cf. German Nutzniessung 'usufruct, profit', OIr. Nuadu < *Newd-ont- 'Fisher'). Alternative etyma might be Ved. návate 'bellow, bray, shout; exult, acclaim, praise', Toch. AB nu- 'shout' (Neumann, apud Tischler, Glossar L-M-N 354]), or Gk. νεύω, Lat. nuō 'nod, assent'. Kloekhorst The word either occurs in lists of good things, always followed by ištamaššuar or tummantia-, or it occurs as an interjection (then nu-ú) in nu-ú halzai-i to call “nū”’. Since tummantia- is the Luwian correspondent to Hitt. ištamaššuar, and because of the one attestation with a gloss-wedge, some scholars regard nū- as a Luwian word, which would explain the dat.sg. form nūti: in Luwian, word-final -t- is dropped. This would mean, however, that a Luwian nū(t)- already in OH times was reshaped to Hitt. nom.sg. nūš and acc.sg.n n. Whether or not this is probable, the exact meaning of the word cannot be determined, which makes etymologizing impossible.

semantic derivation: milk → poppy milk → drowsy → soothing
IE_cognates: Gk. γάλα(κτ)-, γλαγος 'milk', Hom. γλακτοφάγος 'milk-eating', Lat. lac(t)- 'milk' (the quintessential nutrient), Vedic jálāṣa- 'soothing' (< *galaĝso-?), Lith. glẽžnas (<*gleĝno-), ON klökkr (< *glenĝwo-) 'slack, tender'.
comments: Puhvel (HED K 18-20): PIE *g(l̥)l-n̥-ĝ-. Giiterbock (JAOS 103:161-162 [1983]) conjectured in KUB 24.7 I 45 a denominative verb 2 sg. pres. act. [ga]-la-ak-(a-ra-si in the sense of 'make drowsy'; he thought of galaktar as a plant or a vegetal substance and of a possible meaning 'poppy-milk', yet did not identify it outright with Papaver somniferum. kalank- resembles hamank- (q. v.) in having petrified nasal infixation, i.e. *g(l̥)l-n̥-ĝ-. Rather than assuming phonetic loss of /n/ in galaktar (thus e.g. Kammenhuber, MIO 2:418 [1954]; Kronasser, Etym. 1:89, 103), it may be a verbal noun based on the non-infixed stem. Possible cognates are Gk. γάλα(κτ)-, γλαγος 'milk', Hom. γλακτοφάγος 'milk-eating', Lat. lac(t)- 'milk' (the quintessential nutrient), Vedic jálāṣa- 'soothing' (< *galaĝso-?), Lith. glẽžnas (<*gleĝno-), ON klökkr (< *glenĝwo-) 'slack, tender'. Cf. Juret, Vocabulaire 11; Ivanov, Obsceindoevropejskaja 39; T. Burrow, W. B. Henning Memorial Volume 89-97 (1970); Oettinger, Stammbildung 149.

semantic derivation: be silent → be calm
IE_cognates: Lith. gùrstu 'subside, die down', Toch. A kur-, B kwär- 'become feeble, age', Goth, qaírrus 'gentle', qaírrei 'meekness', ON kvirr 'quiet, paceful', Arm. aorist koreay 'die out', korust 'extermination
comments: Puhvel (HED K:116-117; 82-83): For etymology cf. s. v. kariya- 'stop, pause, rest' (82-83). Its uses parallel those of karussiyanu- (q. v.). The base verbs kariya- and karus(siya)- 'be silent' have similar intransitive meanings and probably the same etymology. Cf. Lith. gùrstu 'subside, die down', Toch. A kur-, B kwär- 'become feeble, age', Goth, qaírrus 'gentle', qaírrei 'meekness', ON kvirr 'quiet, paceful', Arm. aorist koreay 'die out', korust 'extermination'. Thus IE *gwer- in kariya- (*gwr̥-y-?) and karus- (*gwr-éw-s-?). For delabialization of *gw- before r see s. v. karap-. See also in eDiAna: https://www.ediana.gwi.uni-muenchen.de/dictionary.php?lemma=1226; https://www.ediana.gwi.uni-muenchen.de/dictionary.php?lemma=1269

comments: Indo-European 'tear' words are mostly (except Slavic [Russian sleza] and Albanian [lot]) traceable to *daḱru- (<*draḱ-ru-: Gk. δάκρυ, Lat. lacruma, Olr. dēr, Goth, tagr, OHG zahar), *draḱur (Arm. artawsr), *draḱnu- (OHG trahan), *aḱru (Ved. áśru, Avest. asrū-, Toch. A ākär [pl. A ākrunt, B akrūna], Lith. ašarà). ishahru is clearly the basic spelling, with the occasional ēshahru influenced by the proximity of ēshar on the "calamity lists" (e.g. KUB VII 41 Vs. 18-19); hence the i- may be phonetically and/or orthographically prothetic (cf. e.g. ishiya-), and a possible reconstruction is *sH1aH1ru-. Oettinger posited ishahru<*sA1aḱru (s-mobile + [A1]aḱru, with h<k as in occasional hazhara- <hazgara-), where the attestation of s-mobile before laryngeal would be chiastically proportionate to Hitt. he(w)u-: Toch. A swase, OPruss. suge 'rain' (*[s]E2ew-H2-). In that case *A1aḱru can hardly be a secondary aberration from *daḱru (the a- vocalism of the latter being also unexplained); there is rather *(s-)A1aḱru- besides *(d-)A1aḱ-ru>*daḱru-, but with occasional *A1>*r in some forms of Indo-European (Arm. artawsr<*draḱur, OHG trahan<*draḱ-nu-), comparable to the Hittite alternation wahnu-: warnu-; another trace of such "d-mobile" may be seen in Lith. ilgas 'long' besides the more usual d-forms (Skt. dīrghá-, etc.), or in Ved. áhar 'day' beside OE dōgor. *A1aḱru- conceivably has basic truck with *aḱri-, aḱro- (Skt. áśri- 'edge', Gk. ἄκρις 'point, peak', Lat. ācer, Lith. ašrús, OCS ostrǔ 'sharp'), in the sense of 'bitter, acrid (fluid)' (cf. the universal cliche 'bitter tears'). A clause from ASSUR letter f+g, § 7 read in CHLI (HAWKINS 2000: 536, cf. 550) as follows: "|“*476”-wa/i-pa-wa/i (*476.*311)ḫi-ru-ra+a-ti-i |ARḪA |wa/i-la-u-ta". The sequence read as ASḪA-ḫi-ru-ra+a-ti can be interpreted phonetically as as ḫaḫ(e)ruradi which can be analyzed as an abl.-instr.sg. form of asḫaḫ(e)rur-. As a result, the passage can now be interpreted as expressing the idea of ‘eyes dying out from tears’. NB! The mainstream meaning in eDiAna for ASḪA-ḫi-ru-ra+a-ti -- about CURSE and OATH, see https://www.ediana.gwi.uni-muenchen.de/dictionary.php?lemma=3571.

comments: PAnat *u̯āi! ‘woe’. The presence of the word (u)wāi- c. ‘woe’ in both Hittite and Luwian allows us to reconstruct a Proto-Anatolian pre-form. The onomatopoetic character of the word, which can be associated with a cry of pain, leads us to a reconstruction with the vowel -a-, i.e. *u̯āi!. Kloekhorst (EDHIL:939) agrees with the onomatopoetic origin of the word, but suggests that (u)wāi- is nevertheless a derivative of ú-i ‘whee!’ attested in Hittite (KUB 55.38 ii 19). Although it is morphologically possible that (u)wāi- is a morphological creation after (Hittite) diphthong stems in -āi- c., it is not necessary either to posit a derivation. Both ú-i and ú-wa-a-i can be independent onomatopoetic creations, in which the latter became fully lexicalized as a declining noun with the meaning ‘woe’. For the Hittite phrase a-i-in ú-wa-a-i-in see HEG U-Z:170f. and EDHIL:939. Besides PAnat. *u̯āi̯- c. ‘woe’, a noun is attested in distant parts of the IE world (Av., Celt., Germ., Alb.). Thus, the noun may be reconstructed for the proto-language as PIE *u̯ai̯- ‘woe’. “Root” etymology: various non-Anatolian languages (Av., Gk., Lat., Celt., Germ., Balt., Alb.) attest an interjection PIE *u̯ai̯!, which expresses pain, sorrow, grief, etc., thus ‘alas!’ vel sim.

comments: HED: PIE *h2órt-ei / *h2urt-énti?. *h2uert; *H1wer(t)- (vs. *wer-[E-] in weriya-) with a more specific meaning than the overworked 'feierlich sprechen'. Plausible cognates are Skt. vrata- 'vow', OCS rota 'oath', OPr. wer-temmai 'we swear', and perhaps (in malam partem) Russ. vrat' 'lie', OCS vraci 'conjurer, magician, physician' Kloekhorst 372 ḫuart-i / ḫurt- (IIa1 > IIa1) ‘to curse’ IE cognates: ?OPr. wertemmai ‘we swear’. Sturtevant (1930d: 128) connected this verb with Lat. verbum ‘word’, Lith. vadas ‘name’, OPr. wirds ‘word’, Goth. waurd ‘word’. Puhvel (l.c.) rejects this etymology because he assumes that these latter words are derived from the root found in Gr.‘to speak’ and Hitt. erie/a-zi ‘to call, to name’: since Hitt. erie/a- does not show an initial laryngeal whereas Hitt. uart-i / urt- does, he claims that the connection cannot be correct. This reasoning is questionable, however, in view of the fact that Hitt. erie/a-zi must reflect *uerh1- (because of Gr. "(fut.)), which is impossible for Lith. vadas, which must reflect *ordho- (a preform **orh1dho-would have yielded Lith. **várdas). So, formally, Sturtevant’s connection between uart-i / urt- and Lat. verbum etc. is still possible: it would mean that we have to reconstruct a root *h2uerdh -. The semantic connection between ‘to curse’ and ‘name, word’ is not compelling, however. Puhvel (l.c.) proposed a different etymology, namely a connection with OPr. wertemmai ‘we swear’. This connection is semantically more likely and would point to a root *h2uert-. The absence of any other IE cognates is unpleasant, however. *h2ēru̯o- ‘oath’ Laroche 1955a:78-81 first elucidated the meaning of ḫīrūn/t- by equating it with Hitt. lengai- c. ‘oath’. After Otten 1953a:95 n. 166 had noticed that ḫīrūn/t- has a negative connotation, Laroche pointed out the following features of the word: a) it is used as a modifier of ‘tongue’ and ‘lord’, b) it is also collocated with taparu- ‘(something negative, humiliation, https://www.ediana.gwi.uni-muenchen.de/dictionary.php?lemma=3567)’ and tātariyam(ma)n- ‘curse’ in Luwian, c) it is used as an epithet of Išḫara and the Sun-god functioning as a guardian and witness of oath, respectively, d) EME ‘tongue’ is modified by the genitival attributes lengai- ‘oath’ and ḫurtai- ‘oath’ in Hittite. Taken together, the evidence allows to equate semantically ḫīrūn/t- with lengai- ‘oath’. Laroche’s interpretation was generally accepted and soon entered the handbooks; Vedic ā́-aryanti ‘they appreciate, acknowledge’, āritá- ‘acknowledged’, ncient Greek ἀρά, Ionic ᾱ̓ρή f. ‘prayer, vow, curse’ (Il.+) < *aru̯ā́, Arcadian κάταρϝος ‘cursed’, (?) IE_cognates: Skt. marc- ‘to hurt, to damage’, Lat. murcus ‘mutilated’
comments: According to Knobloch (1959: 39), followed by Oettinger (1979a: 346)), this verb belongs with Skt. marc- ‘to hurt, to damage’ and Lat. murcus ‘mutilated’. semantic derivation: to be savage → to rage → to be hostile
IE_cognates: Ved. hvarate 'deviate', Avest. zurah- 'iniquity', OCS zverъ, Lith. zveris, Lat. furor 'rage', Skt. krūrá- ‘bloody’
comments: Puhvel (285) Somewhat like kallar- 'balefulness' (q.v.), kurur- is at the base an abstract neuter noun which has diversified a bit via appositional juxtaposition and specific derivation, partly on the model of Akk. nakdru. Despite Benveniste's despairing "isole et inanalysable" (Origines 37), kurur- was improbably connected with Skt. krura- 'bloody, cruel', Lat. eruor 'blood', crudus 'raw' (etc.) from H. Holma (Jour- nal de la Soeiete finno-ougrienne 33.1:66 [1916]) and Hrozny (Heth KB 137) to Sturtevant (Lg. 6:217 [1930], Comp. Or.1 32, Comp Gr2 56-7) and beyond, possibly as a dissimilatory *krurur (Kronasser, Etym. 1:103). Sturtevant himself launched a dubious parallel derivation of kurur- from kucr- 'cut' (Comp. Gr.] 119, 148) which lin-gered through Laroche (BSL 58:69 [1963]), Carruba (Beschwo-rungsritual 53, with wrong reference to Sturtevant), Gusmani (Lessico 117), and Oettinger (Stammhildung 120). Van Windekens (Arch.Or. 57:336 [1989]) thought of Gk. Papvq 'heavy'.H. Eichner's brief suggestion (MSS 31:75, 99 [1973]) kurur < *ghwr-\\r 'crookedness, deceit' and adduction of Ved. hvarate 'deviate', Avest. zurah- 'iniquity' was featured by Mayrhofer {KEWA 3:620) but remains semantically dubious and under the lingering cloud of Lai. falio 'deceive' and IE *gh\vel- (IEW489-90) as etyma of the Indo-Iranian words. Mayrhofer {KEWA 3:620) connected *ghwer- 'walk crookedly' with *gh\ver- 'wild beast' (Gk. Ofjp, OCS zverL Lith. zveris, Lat.ferns). This is very doubtful, but *gh\ver- itself may hold the clue to kurur-, with a root-meaning 'be savage, rage'; a *gh\vr-\vr 'savagery' may hence stand as the proto-form underlying kurur-. It might even be worth considering whether *gh\vr-wr holds the key also to the reshaped Lat. furor 'rage', since other etymologies for furo 'to rage' (*bhuro, *dhuso, *dhuro) are all flawed (see Walde-Mofmann and Ernout-Meillet s. v.), leaving the possibility of *ghuro (cf. fundo < *ghud-no). Semantically kurur- and furor make sense as referring originally to warlike fury, same as Irish ferg and German Wut (cf. the glossing of Wodan by 'Furor' [Adam of Bremen 4.26]).

semantic derivation: to push away → forsake, abandon → neglect → be unfriendly
IE_cognates: Goth. af-skiuban ‘push away, forsake, abandon’
luw: puškantatar; puškant(i)- HLuw. paskw- ‘to neglect’; pa-sà-REL-i (/paskwi/)'‘neglects’'
hitt: puškant(i)- ‘aloof (?), unfriendly (?); ’paškuwae-, pašku- (ант  (ḫuišnu-) 'aloofness'; V pašku- ‘to reject, to ignore; to neglect; to remove’ (EDHIL 651-652); V pasku(wai)- ‘abandon, forsake, dismiss, disown, discharge’ (HED Pa:190-192)
comments: Kloekhorst (651): pašku-zi (Ib1 > Ic2) ‘to reject, to ignore; to neglect; to remove’: The original stem is pašku-, which is visible in the MS forms paškutta and paškuanzi. Especially the form 3sg.pret.act. paškutta (and not **paškut) shows that we have to phonologically interpret this stem as /paskw-/. In NH times, the trivial transition into the atrae-class yielded forms like paškunun and paškuwait. In HLuwian, we find a verbal form pa-sà-REL-i ‘neglects’ which likely is to be interpreted as /paskwi/ (note the i-inflection), which would indicate that the PAnat. form was *Paskw- (since *gw would have disappeared in Luwian). This is supported by the PN f Pa-aš-ku-a-am-mi-iš (KUB 31.59 ii 4), which formally is to be interpreted as a Luwian participle of a stem pašku(a)-. Kloekhorst knows of no IE cognates, however. Puhvel (HED Pa:190-192), A. Carnoy (La Nouvelle Clio 6: 231 [1954]) suggested *pa-sqeu- (comparing Lat. obscūrus), pasku- joins pastar(iya)- (q. v.) in attesting pa- matching Hitt. pe-. A verb pa-sku- resembles Goth. af-skiuban ‘push away, forsake, abandon’.

semantic derivation: to leave, abandon → defiecient → defective → not right → sin
IE_cognates: Ved.  ūná- ‘wanting, deficient, defective’ (AV+; cf. án-ūna- ‘unfailing, inexhaustible’ RV [+] ), Av. ūnā- ‘deficient (offering)’, Arm. ownayn ‘empty’,  Lati. vānus ‘empty’,  Proto-Germanic *wanaz ‘deficient, lacking (in)’ (Gothic wans, Old Norse vanr, Old English, Old High German wan
hitt: waštul- (var. uštul-) wašta-/wašt-(ḫi) ‘to sin, offend’ wašku(i); waštul- /waštanu-
comments: *h1u̯eh2- ‘leave, abandon, lose’ Vedic vā́yati ‘fades away, becomes empty, lacks, loses’ and Ancient Greek ἐάω ‘abandon, leave behind, leave alone’ (whence ‘let be, allow, permit’; see Nussbaum 1998b:79). An absolute intransitive meaning ‘quit, fail, be deficient’ (see Nussbaum 1998b:81–83) is suggested by Latvian vâjêt ‘become weak’ and a couple of nominal formations, including adjectives in *-(o)no- such as *h1uh2-no- > Vedic ūná- ‘wanting, deficient, defective’ (AV+; cf. án-ūna- ‘unfailing, inexhaustible’ RV [+] ), Avestan ūnā- ‘deficient (offering)’, Armenian ownayn ‘empty’, *h1u̯eh2-no- > Latin vānus ‘empty’, *h1uh2-ono- > Proto-Germanic *wanaz ‘deficient, lacking (in)’ (Gothic wans, Old Norse vanr, Old English, Old High German wan, etc.). It is not surprising that formations in this semantic range can adopt meanings of negative value judgment (e.g., Latin vānus ‘empty’ and ‘false, lying, deceptive, delusive, untrustworthy’, and further English fail and failure, German fehlen ‘to be missing’ and Verfehlung ‘wrongdoing, transgression’). In this regard, it is important to note that Hittite wašta-/wašt-(ḫi) also means ‘to miss (a target)’ (cf. Puhvel 1992a:7; HEG W-Z:406), which might preserve the older meaning. Kloekhorst 931 Derivatives: wašdulae-zi (Ic2) ‘to offend’ wašdulaant- ‘offense’ PIE *usTh2/3-éul This word clearly is cognate with ašta-i / ašt- ‘to sin’ (q.v.). Although the bulk of the attestations of this word show a stem wašdul-, the oldest ones show wuštul-. This latter stem therefore must have been the original one. Apparently, the zero grade stem ušt- of uštul- was replaced by ašt- in the early MH period, probably in analogy to the full grade stem of the verb. The fact that we find an original zero grade root in this noun implies that the suffix -ul- must have been accented, which is supported by the spelling a-aš-du-ú-li, which must reflect *-éul-i. See s.v. ašta-i / ašt- for further etymology. Note that despite the one NS commune form acc.sg.c. ašdulin all other forms clearly indicate that the word is neuter.

semantic derivation: to press, to apply pressure physically → to press / put pressure on someone psychologically
IE_cognates: Gr. εdαmασα ‘to tame’, OIr. damnaim ‘to tie up’, Skt. damyáti ‘to tame’, Lat. domre ‘to tame’
comments: *dméh2-s-ti / dmh2-s-énti. *dmaHs-/*dmHs- PIE n‑pres. *dm̥‑né/n‑h2‑, cf. Ved. damāyáti ‘to tame, oppress’ (refashioned, EWAia I:698, Grassmann 1996a:576f.), Gk. δάμνημι, Dor. δάμνᾱμι ‘to tame, subdue, conquer (esp. of horses)’ (GEW I:346, DELG:250f., EDG:301, LSJ:368), OIr. damnaim ‘to subdue, break in (of horses)’ (eDIL s.v. 2.damnaid, EDPC:88) PIE iter. *domh2‑éi̯e/o‑, cf. Ved. damáyati ‘to tame’, Khot. dīm‑/danda- ‘to tame’, Oss. domyn/dæmun ‘to tame, exhaust, request’ (EWAia I:698, Grassmann 1996a:576f., EDIV:55, Abaev I:365f.), Lat. domāre ‘to tame’ (WH I:367f., EM:182, EDLIL:178), PGerm. *tamjan- (Goth. ga‑tamjan [hapax, Mk.5.4], ON temja ‘to tame’, OHG zemman) [+] (EDPG:508, GED:149f., Bjorvand & Lindeman 2000a:922, Kluge & Seebold 2011a: 1001, Heidermanns 1993a:589f.) Celtic OIr. daimid ‘to endure, suffer’ (eDIL s.v. daimid, EDPC:89f.) Regarding the Anatolian semantics, the meaning of PAnat. *dmaHs- ‘to press (physically)’ [+] is primary, and ‘to oppress (psychologically)’ secondary, [+] cf. Buck 1949a:575. The meaning ‘to tame’ of PIE 2.*demh2- can be established only for a fairly recent stage of Core IE, while the original meaning has to be approximated as ‘to press (physically)’.2. Connection with PIE *dem- ‘to build’ A connection of PIE 2.*demh2- ‘to press, oppress’ (contra LIV²:116f., cf. above) with PIE 1.*dem- ‘to assemble, build’ is frequently assumed. [+] A factitive relation seems plausible: ‘to build’, ‘house’ → ‘to make appropriate for living by a house’ > ‘to domesticate, tame’. However, since the primary meaning of PIE 2.*demh2- is ‘to press (physically)’, this development is impossible. In order to connect both roots, the original meaning of 1.*dem- ‘to build, assemble’ can hence be approximated as ‘to press on, compress (clay vel sim.)’, [+] thus: (early) PIE *dem- ‘to press (physically)’> PIE 1.*dem- ‘to press on, compress (clay vel sim.)’ > ‘to build, assemble’ (cf. Lyd. tam- ‘to build’)→ PIE 2.*demh2- ‘to press (physically)’ (cf. PAnat. *dmaH‑s‑) > ‘to oppress (cf. PAnat. *dmaH‑s‑); to tame (cf. Gk. δάμνημι)’ The meanings ‘to build, assemble’ and ‘to (op)press’, might exhibit a polysemy that already existed in PIE. For the root-final *‑h2- in PIE 2.*demh2- ‘to press’, cf. below. Kloekhorst 825 damme/iš- (c.) ‘damaging, act of violence, punishment’: IE cognates: see s.v. tamšš-zi / tame/išš-. Gr. 0‘to tame’, OIr. damnaim ‘to tie up’, Skt. damyáti ‘to tame’, Lat. domre ‘to tame’.PIE *demh2-sh2ó- See Otten 1973: 52 for attestations. This noun and its derivatives are almost consistently spelled with the sign DAM. Although in NS texts this sign can be read dax as well (see e.g. tamšš-zi / tame/išš- and ištamašš-zi (s.v. (UZU)ištman- / ištamin-)), its usage in MS texts and especially the OS attestation t-m-[m]i-iš ha-an-ta-an show that all attestations should be read with geminate -mm-. We find spellings with -i- as well as -e- in MS texts already, which points to a phonological interpretation /taMsH-/. Already Götze (1930: 179) connected damme/iš- with the verb tamšš-zi / tame/išš- ‘to oppress’. Although this is generally accepted, the fact that damme/iš- shows geminate -mm-, whereas tamašš-zi / tame/išš- does not, is significant. As I have argued s.v. tamšš-zi / tame/išš-, this verb has to be phonologically interpreted /tmS-/, /tmS-/ and goes back to *dméh2-s-ti, *dmh2-s-énti. The noun damme/iš- must be phonologically interpreted /taMsH-/, however, with a real vowel -a- between d- and -mm-. This vowel can only reflect a real PIE vowel. I therefore reconstruct *demh2-sh2ó-. For the development of *CeRHsC > CaRRsC compare kallišta /káLsta/ ‘called’ < *élh1st(o). For the suffix -ša- compare e.g. palza()a-, ameša-, teša-, etc. Иванов 175

IE_cognates: Goth. lewjan ‘to betray’, Lith. liáutis ‘to stop’, Ukr. livýty ‘to omit, to neglect’
comments: Kloekhorst 534 luri- (c. > n.) ‘loss of honour, disgrace, humiliation; financial loss; shortage(?)’ (Sum. I.BÍ.ZA): Derivatives: lriatar (n.) ‘disgrace, humiliation’ (nom.-acc.sg. [l]u-u-ri-a-tar (NH)), lria-i (IIb) ‘to humiliate, to disgrace’ (3sg.pret.act. lu-ri-a-a-ta (NH),2sg.imp.act. lu-u-ri-a-a (NH), 3pl.imp.act. lu-ri-a-a-a-an-du (OH/NS), impf. lu-u-ri-a-a-i-eš-ke/a- (NH)). PIE *léh1u-ri-s, *léh1u-ri-m, *lh1u-réi-s ? See CHD L-M: 86f. for attestations. About the semantics it states: “the unifying idea seems to be ‘loss’, whether of possessions, honour or station”. The word shows many plene spellings of the -u-, for which predominantly the sign U is used. Twice, we find the sign Ú, however. Either these two instances are scribal errors, or we are dealing with traces of an original ablaut between lu-u-ri- = /lóri-/ and lu-ú-ri- = /lri-/ (see § 1.3.9.4f and below). The oldest attestations show commune gender, whereas the one neuter form is attested in a NH text only. According to Puhvel (HED 5: 123), l ri- is to be analysed as a deverbal noun in -ri-, just as edri- ‘food’, šri- ‘shape’ etc. that are derived from ed-zi / ad- ‘to eat’ and eš-zi / aš- ‘to be’ respectively. If this is correct, we may think of a connection with the verbal root *leh1-, which shows a u-present in e.g. Goth. lewjan ‘to betray’, Lith. liáutis ‘to stop’, Ukr. livýty ‘to omit, to neglect’. Perhaps lu-ú-ri- = /lri-/ reflects *leh1u-ri-, whereas lu-u-ri- = /lóri-/ reflects *lh1u-ri-.

IE_cognates: Skt. dabhrá- ‘little, small, deficient’, dabhnóti ‘to deceive, to hurt’, ádbhuta- ‘unerring, wunderful’, GAv. dbnao- ‘to deceive’

comments: Kloekhorst (869): from tēpu- / tēpau- (adj.) ‘little, few’: IE cognates: Skt. dabhrá- ‘little, small, deficient’, dabhnóti ‘to deceive, to hurt’, ádbhuta- ‘unerring, wunderful’, GAv. dbnao- ‘to deceive’.PIE *dhébh-u- This noun and its derivatives are predominantly spelled te-e-p° and te-p° (both in OStexts already). Twice, we find an aberrant spelling, namely [t]i-e-pu (OS) andz[e-]-pu (OS), but these can hardly be anything else than scribal errors. This adjective, which has to be phonologically interpreted /tébu- / tébau-/ has since Marstrander (1919: 150) generally been connected with Skt. dabhrá- ‘little, small, deficient’. At the same time Hrozný (1919: 1464) connected Hitt. tepnu-zi with Skt.dabhnóti ‘to deceive’, which goes back to *dhebh-neu- (but note that GAv. dbnao- = /dbnao-/ shows the most archaic formation, namely *dbh-neu-). A u-stem, as in Hitt. tpu-, is found in Skt. ádbhuta- ‘unerring, wunderful’ (*.-dhbh-u-to-) as well.See s.v. tepšu- / tepša- for a nominal derivative reflecting *dhebh-su-. See also Luw. taparu- 'humiliation' (https://www.ediana.gwi.uni-muenchen.de/dictionary.php?lemma=3567).

semantic derivation: hostility → revenge
IE_cognates: OIr. cath‘strife, battle’
hitt: kattu- ‘enmity, strife’; kattuwae-, kattawatar  'to be aggrieved'; katterraḫḫ-
comments: Kloekhorst (466): PIE *k̑h2et-(e)u- ? Derivatives: kattuae-zi (Ic2) ‘to be aggrieved(?)’ (3sg.pret.act. kad-du-u-a-i[t] (OH/NS), kad-du-a-i-i[t] (OH/NS)), kattatar / kattawann- (n.) ‘aggrievedness, enmity’ (nom.-acc.sg. kat-ta-a-a-tar (OH/NS), kat-ta-a-tar (OH/MS), gen.sg. kat-ta-a-an-na-aš (OH/NS)), kattaannalli- (adj.) ‘vengeful’ (nom.sg.c. kat-ta-a-‹an-›na-al-li-iš (MH/NS)). See Puhvel HED 4: 138f. for attestations. Although the basic noun kattu- is only attested once, on the basis of the derivatives kattuae- and kattaatar we can set up an adjective *kattu- / katta- ‘aggrieved, inimical’. Laroche (1965: 51) compared these words to Gr. ‘spite, anger’, which is usually connected with OIr. cath‘strife, battle’ (which reflects *katu- as in the personal names Gaul. Catu-riges, OHG Hadu-brand), MHG hader ‘fight, struggle’ and Skt. sátru- ‘enemy’. These words point to a root *h2et- (laryngeal needed to explain OIr. -a-), which would mean that Hitt. kattu- / katta- reflects *h2et-eu-. Note that this implies that CLuw. kattawatnalli- cannot be genuinely Luwian, since * > Luw. z-, and therefore must be an adaptation of the Hittite word. https://www.ediana.gwi.uni-muenchen.de/dictionary.php?lemma=3777

semantic derivation: high → eminent, powerful → arrogant
IE_cognates: TochB särk- ‘to be better than’, Lat. sarci ‘to patch up, to mend'
comments: Kloekhorst (734): šarku- / šarga- (adj.) ‘eminent, illustrious, powerful’, (c.) ‘an eminent person’. IE cognates: TochB särk- ‘to be better than’, Lat. sarci ‘to patch up, to mend’. PIE *sr-(e)u- or *sor-(e)u- This adjective is often translated ‘high in status’(cf. also CHD), which goes back to Juret (1942: 43) who assumed an inner-Hittite connection with šar ‘upwards’ and šr ‘on top’. This connection cannot be correct, however, and šarku- / šarga- therefore should be translated ‘eminent, illustrious, powerful’ without semantically linking it to ‘high’. We are clearly dealing with an u-stem adjective derived from a root šark-, which probably is found as such in the verb šarkiške/a- ‘to be good’ < *šark-ške/a-. Note that the editors of CHD (Š: 267) translate this verb as “to ascend”, which they admit to have based “on the supposed link to šarku- ‘high, eminent’”. Moreover, in order to illustrate this meaning they only cite one context, KUB 24.7 iv 25-26, which is broken and therefore non probative. The other context in which this verb occurs is much clearer (for the reading šar-[k]i-iš-ke-ši, cf. šarku- d UTU-u- ‘eminent Sun-god’ in ibid. i 15, 18, 58).

semantic derivation: separate, distant → foreign / alien → hostile → envious
IE_cognates: ME ellendish ‘foreign’, Lat alius ‘other’, aliēnus ‘alien’, aliā ‘elsewhere’, aliās ‘elsewhere, at another time’, Gk ἄλλος, proclitic adversative conjunction ἀλλά ‘but’, Arm. ayl (o-stem) ‘other, different’, Ved. arí, aryá-, áraṇa- ‘alien, remote’
translation: enmity; envious person, covetousness; to become envious, covet, enemy force
luw: /alan(na)-/, á-lá/í-na- ; alanna/i- /aliwann(i)-, alunn(i)-/, ali-wa/i-ní-; /(a)liwannid-/, (VIR2)ali-wa/i-ní-, /alunam(i)-/, (“COR”)á-la/i/u-na-ma-; /alunazza-(i)/, (COR)á-la/i/u-na-za from HL /ala-i/, see alienation āla/i- ‘distant (?)’ /arla-/, ara/i-la- ‘pedestal, altar (?)’
comments: As demonstrated by Rieken & Yakubovich 2022a:278f. (accepted in Steitler 2017a:390, 395), Anatolian inherited the root *al- ‘not related to the speaker’ with derivatives that show a range of metaphorically transferred meanings: ‘other’, ‘distant’, ‘foreign’, ‘hostile’, and ‘wild’. Earlier interpretations took other directions. Thus, Watkins 1995b:144-147 claimed that āla/i- means ‘high, lofty, steep’ and was borrowed into Mycenean Greek, appearing as the first member in the Greek compound ᾱλίβατος (Pindar, Aeschylus), ἤλίβατος (Homer) ‘steep (rock)’. This interpretation was presented already in Watkins 1986a:714f. n. 29, accepted in CLL:6, and considered in HHw:13. In contrast, Starke 1990a:603 argued that Luw. āla/i- is unlikely to function as the word for ‘steep, high’, since this meaning is expressed by Luw. parrai(ya)-. Instead, Starke 1990a:374 n. 1346 and 462 n. 1683 (repeated in HHW:13) suggested that the lexeme in question represents the noun for ‘sea’, regarding it as a cognate of Lyc. A elijãna ‘nymphs’. Starke’s interpretation of ala/i- ultimately went back to Carruba 1962a:65f. (repeated in Carruba 1982:47f.), HW:475, Laroche 1979:114; still very vague Meriggi 1957:215 and without any assignment of a meaning DLL:25f. PIE endingless locative *al and i-locative *al-i ‘elsewhere’ (Pokorny IEW 24‑27; Specht 1943a:49f., Dunkel LIPP II 18‑21); delocatival derivatives: *al, *al-i ‘elsewhere’ → *alo-, *ali̯o- ‘being elsewhere, other’ Tocharian B m. alyek, f. alyāk, n. allek; A m. ālak, f. ālyāk, n. ālak (Winter 1992c:151‑158); derivative B aletse ‘foreign’ Germanic Goth. aljis ‘other’, OHG eli-lentī ‘existence in foreign territory’ [Dasein in der Fremde] (EWAhd II.1044), Middle English ellendish ‘foreign’ Latin alius ‘other’, aliēnus ‘alien’, aliā ‘elsewhere’, aliās ‘elsewhere, at another time’ Ancient Greek ἄλλος, proclitic adversative conjunction ἀλλά ‘but’ (Hackstein 2011b) Classical Armenian ayl (o-stem) ‘other, different’ (Olsen 1999a:25) Vedic Sanskrit arí, aryá-, áraṇa- ‘alien, remote’. See in eDiAna: https://www.ediana.gwi.uni-muenchen.de/dictionary.php?lemma=3210. As for semantics, see also niwaralla-.

semantic derivation: to spread out → to spread out one's arms → to hug → to intertwine → a loop, to tighten (physically) → metaphorical shift → a difficult state, depression, feeling of being constrained by circumstances → (physical, in the body) restlessness → fear
IE_cognates: Goth. fatha ‘fence,  Slav. petъlja (Russ. петля)
comments: Puhvel (HED 113) The spelling pı ́-tu-li-ya-an guarantees the reading pı ́t- (rather than pa ́t-), while its hapax scriptio facilior does not shake -tt- in pı ́t-tu-, pointing to //t// and etymological *t. Cf. perhaps Goth. fatha ‘fence’, if originally ‘enclosure, corral’, possibly from *pet-A2- ‘spread’ as in pattar, pittalwa-, where the semantics would have to include ‘enfold,embrace’ (thus Rieken, Stammbildung 4712; cf. German um-fassen). Underlying the derivatives is a noun *pittul- ‘constriction’(type of assul-, taksul-, wastul-), with *si ́g pittulas ‘wool of constric- tion’ hypostasized as (SI ́G)pittula- ‘skein (of wool)’, Kloekhorst (681): The meanings ‘loop, knot’ (for (SÍG)pittula-) and ‘anguish, worry’ (for pittulia- and derivatives) seem to be connected by the notion ‘choking, strangling’, but I have been unable to find a formally fitting cognate with such a meaning. According to Rieken (1999a: 471-2), we have to start from a stem pittul- which she analyses as an -ul-derivative of the root *peth2- ‘to spread out’, assuming a semantic development ‘*ausbreiten’ > ‘*Arme ausbreiten’ > ‘*umfassen’ > ‘umschlingen’. (*расправить' > '*развести руки' > '*обнять' > 'окружить'.) This development does not seem very appealing to me. Molina: E.Rieken (1999) believes that there was a suffixal formation *peth2-ul- here and, accordingly, a semantic transition from "to spread out > to spread out one's arms > to hug > to intertwine. I.Yakubovich (2016) draws a parallel with Slav. petъlja (Russ. петля), with a very close semantic formation. All in all, semantic transition from the concept of a knot to the concept of being restrained, anxious, worried sounds trivial and typologically frequent.

semantic derivation: *u̯er-eh1- 'notice, attention' + *deh1- 'put' → to focus attention (on something) → to be wary of something → to be afraid of something (→ “to frighten, to scare”)
IE_cognates: Lat. vereor ‘show respect,  OIr. cóīr, coair ‘full- fledged’, Wel. cyweir ‘prepared’ < Proto-Celt. *ko(m)-wari-; Goth. wars, OIsl. varr, OEng. wœr- ‘accurate, attentive’ (Proto-Germ. *wara-), Goth. warei ‘sly’, OEng. waru, OHGerm. wara ‘attention’.
comments: Kloekhorst (1004): PIE *w(e)rh1-i- + *dheh1- ? First it should be noted that although the bulk of the forms of this verb are spelled ú-e-ri-, we find two OS attestations that show wa-ri- with an aberrant -wa-. The one form that is spelled ú-i-ri- is attested in a NS text and can therefore be disregarded for etymological purposes. The fact that we find a stem erite- (ú-e-ri-ti-iz[-zi], ú-e-ri-te-eš-ta and weritema-) besides a stem e/arit- (ú-e-ri-iz-za-aš-ti /ueritsti/,waritanzi, ú-e-ri-ta[-an-zi] and eridanu-) reminds of verbs like peute-zi / peut-,uate-zi / uat- and wete-zi / wet-. These verbs all can probably be traced back to the root *dheh1- ‘to put’ preceded by several univerbated elements. Therefore, it is likely that we/arite-zi / we/arit- also consists of we/ari- + *dheh1-. This view is also advocated by Oettinger (2001: 467), who analyses the verb as *weri-de- ‘zur Verehrung setzen’, apparently connecting the first element with wer(ie/a)-zi ‘to call,to summon’ (q.v.). If this connection is correct, I would rather suggest another semantic development, namely ‘*to place a call > *to scream (in fear) > to fear’. If so, then the OS variant with wari- may show a zero grade formation *wrh1-i- besides the e-grade in werie/a-< *uerh1-e/o-, in analogy to which e-grade was introduced in warit(e)- >> werit(e)-after the OH period. Molina forthcoming: "For werit(e)- (EDHIL: 591, 1003), following Oettinger (2001: 467), suggests PIE form in two parts: *w(e)rh1-i- + dheh1- (weri-dē- in Oettinger, *dē- meaning ‘put’). Semantic development in this case would be ‘start calling > call (in fear) > fear’ (and the connection with Hitt. weriya- ‘to call’ is, of course, suggested, too). Tischler (HEG W-Z:503) mentions this etymology together with another version (first mention – Marstrander 1919), according to which werit(e)- is connected to Lat. vereor ‘show respect, fear, to fear’. De Vaan (2018) reconstructs *wer-ē- ‘to be aware’ for Proto-Italian, and its cognates in Indo-European languages would be: OIr. cóīr, coair ‘full- fledged’, Wel. cyweir ‘prepared’ < Proto-Celt. *ko(m)-wari-; Goth. wars, OIsl. varr, OEng. wœr- ‘accurate, attentive’ (Proto-Germ. *wara-), Goth. warei ‘sly’, OEng. waru, OHGerm. wara ‘attention’. In PIE, accordingly, the form *uer-eh1- ‘notice, have importance’ might be reconstructed. Both etymologies can be combined by proposing a reconstruction: *uer-eh1- + suffix *deh1- > Proto-Hitt. *werē-dē- ‘put in a terrible position, terrify’. "

semantic derivation: [two → to doubt, to be of two minds] → to be surprised, to be frightened, fear → to be afraid
PA_root: PLuw. *du̯ai̯a- ‘to fear’; PA*du̯ói̯-/du̯i-´ ‘to fear’, with the transition  *dw- > *tw- > kw-
IE_cognates: OAv. duuaēθā- f. ‘threat; Gk. δείδω, δείδιμεν perf. ‘fear’ (Hom.), δεινός adj. ‘fearful, terrible, monstrous’, also ‘awesome, strong, extraordinary’ (Il.+), δειλός adj. ‘cowardly, miserable’ (Il.+), δεῖμα n. ‘fear’ (Il.+), Δεῖμος m. ‘Fear’ (personified, Il.), δέος n. ‘fear, alarm, affright’ (Il.+), ἀ-δεής adj. ‘fearless’ (Il.+); Arm. erkea-/erki- aor. midd. ‘to be afraid’, erknčʻi- pres. ‘to be afraid’, erkiwł sbst. ‘fear'.
translation: to fear, revere; respect; frightened; to worry, to be concerned
luw: CL duwayā-(i) ‘to fear, revere’; /kwaya-(i)/, kwa/i-i(a)-; kuwayanta-; kuwayant(i)-; /kwayada-/, kwa/i-ia-ta-; kuwayata-(i)/kwissa-(i)/, kwa/i-sà-; /kwissant(i)-/, hwa/i-sà-ta-; GK kuwayamma/i- ‘fearful’
comments: Puhvel (HED 302)Luw. kuway- < *dway- < * IE *dwey(s)- 'fear', seen in Gk.SeiSco < *d£8foia, Arm. erkneim 'fear', Skt. dvesti 'hate' (oderintdum metuantl; IEW 227-8). With kuwayata- cf. especially Gk. 8ei-voq 'fearsome, formidable'; it can be glossed as Ssivdg elvai (tuk-ma kuwayatallu vs. Iliad 3:172 aidoioq re poi EGGI cpiXe EKvpiSrAvog re), kuwayaralla- < *dwey(e)ro-, matching Lat. dirus and recalling Gk. SeiXog < *dweyelos with kuwayaralla mema- cf. Lat. dlra precari 'to curse'. Cf. Lye. kb < *dw (kbi [Milyan tbi] < *d\vr- 'two' [same root as *dwey-\], kbatra < *du(g)atra 'daughter') and such general parallels as German epier 'oblique' (vs. Swedish ivcir) or Quark 'curds'(vs. Russian tvorog). Cf. Laroche, BSL 62.1:50 (1967); Ivanov, Etimologija 1983 164-5 (1985).Superseded connections involved Skt. cetati 'pay attention' (Cop,Ling. 1:61 [1955]), cayati 'respect', Gk. Tico'rever^ (H. C. Melchert,Studies in Hit lite Historical Phonology 164 [1984]; Studies in memory of W.Cowgill 188 [1987]), thus essentially IE **Vv- (IEW636-7).PLuwian *du̯ai̯a- ‘to fear’; PIE - OAv. duuaēθā- f. ‘threat; Gk. δείδω, δείδιμεν perf. ‘fear’ (Hom.), δεινός adj. ‘fearful, terrible, monstrous’, also ‘awesome, strong, extraordinary’ (Il.+), δειλός adj. ‘cowardly, miserable’ (Il.+), δεῖμα n. ‘fear’ (Il.+), Δεῖμος m. ‘Fear’ (personified, Il.), δέος n. ‘fear, alarm, affright’ (Il.+), ἀ-δεής adj. ‘fearless’ (Il.+); Arm. erkea-/erki- aor. midd. ‘to be afraid’, erknčʻi- pres. ‘to be afraid’, erkiwł sbst. ‘fear'. eDiAna (Sasseville): "Finally, there is also the possibility of relating *du̯ei̯- ‘to get frightened, fear’ and/or *du̯ei̯s- ‘to hate, be hostile’ to PIE *du̯o/i- ‘two(fold)’. Cf., e.g., Watkins 2011a:22 s.v. dwei-, who therefore posits an original meaning *‘to be in doubt, be of two minds’ for *du̯ei̯- (cf. also EIEC:198, EWAia I:770f., EDIV:82)." The acknowledged sound change *dw- > *tw- > kw- (Laroche 1967a:50) did not happened in the Istanuwa Luwian.

semantic derivation: to be crazed with fear, to be terrified, to hate → to be terrified → terror → terrifying, fearsome, formidable
IE_cognates: Gk. odysseo, Lat. odium 'hatred1, Arm. ateam 'I hate',ateli 'hateful, terrible', OB atol, ON atall Tierce, terrible'
comments: Puhvel (HED 275): The most plausible connection for hatuk- (since Gotze — Pedersen,MS 50-1 ) has been with Gk. (aor. inf.) d6m(o)ao0a\ 'be wroth"and its probable cognates Lat. odium 'hatred1, Arm. ateam 'I hate',ateli 'hateful, terrible', OB atol, ON atall Tierce, terrible' (/£W/773),to which Tischler (KZ 92:108-11 [1978]) added Crimean Gothicatochta (glossed by Lat. malum) as a strong-declension nom.-ace.sg. neut. from an *atugs < IE *odu-ko- Kloekhorst 336 PIE *h2téug-ti / *h2tug-énti .The generally accepted etymology is the one first suggested by Benveniste (1937: 497), who connected atuka/i- with Gr. 46 ‘to be distraught from fear, to be terrified’ < *h2tug-, which semantically is convincing indeed. The formal aspect of this etymology is more complicated however. If Hitt. atuk- indeed reflects *h2tug-, it would mean that the initial cluster *h2t- is reflected as Hitt. a-tV- and not **a-at-tV-, as one could have expected. To my knowledge, there are no other examples of such an reflex in Hittite (the often cited parallel apuš- ‘penis’ < *h3pus- is incorrect as the stem actually is pša(šš)- (q.v.), which denotes ‘shin-bone’ and not ‘penis’). On the contrary, forms like appeššar ‘limb’ < *h2p-ésr, attant-clever’ < *h2t-ent- or appanzi ‘they seize’ < *h1penti seem to show that initial clusters /Hp-/, /Ht-/ and /p-/ are spelled with a geminate stop. Nevertheless, all hese forms belong to ablauting verbs which could have caused restitution of the voiceless stop. So, I would like to propose that in *h2tug- the initial cluster *h2t- regularly lenited to Hitt. /Hd-/, spelled a-tV-, whereas in forms that show *HT- as a zero grade of *HeT- the fortis stop *T was restored, which yielded initial clusters /HT-/ and /T-/,spelled a-aT-TV- or aT-TV-.Couvreur (1937: 147) further connected atuk-zi and Gr. 46 with Skt. tuj- ‘tothrust’. Although at first sight this connection is semantically problematic, forms like tujyáte ‘he is put to panic’ may show that this connection is possible. Puhvel (l.c.) dismisses the etymological connection with Gr. 46(without argumentation) and connects atuk-zi with Gr. /04() ‘to be wroth against, to hate’. As this word is connected with Lat. odium ‘to hate’ (from PIE *h3ed-), it must in his view be analysed as a suffixed form *h3ed-u- or *h3d-u-. This does not fit the fact that Hitt. hatuk- clearly functions as a monosyllabic root. Moreover, if the preform were *h3d-u-, the initial *h3 would regularly drop in Hittite before a stop (cf. Kloekhorst 2006b).

semantic derivation: to turn one’s back → to be afraid, to be frightened
IE_cognates: OIr. nar ‘noble, modest’, Gk. νῷτον ‘back’, Lat. natis ‘buttocks’
translation: to fear; fear; terror; terrified; to be of concern; fearsome
comments: PIE *nóh2-ei, nh2énti, *neh2-sr Molina For nāḫḫ- it is customary to reconstruct PIE *neh2-. Keeping in mind that nāḫḫ- and its derivative naḫšaratt-, as well as OIr. nar ‘noble, modest’ coordinate with Gk. νῷτον ‘back’ and Lat. natis ‘buttocks’, Kölligan (2020: 152) suggests that PIE. *neh2- meant ‘to turn (back)’. Now, νῷτον would correlate with the acrostatic paradigm: *nóh2-t-/neh2-t- ‘turning (itr.)’, and natis – amphikinetic one (which can be derived from the acrostatic noun) nom. *neh2-ot-s, gen. *nh2-t-es, loc.*nh2-et-I ‘at the back’, vel. sim. Thus, the back appears to be the same body part that turns from the interlocutor, same as in Lat. dorsum (see Kölligan 2020:146f for typological parallels of semantic transitions ‘to turn one’s back > to fear, to be scared’).

semantic derivation: a ball (made from a cut-off piece?) → a scarecrow → to be afraid — development within the Hittite language
PA_root: PHitt. ku̯er-/kur 'cut' (Hitt.) OR onomatopeia with reduplication
IE_cognates: The similar metaphor: Arm.kosfkocjel- 'smash'
comments: Puhvel (269): Giiterbock (Documentum Otten 115-9J established kurkuriya- as a verbum dicendi (or at least exprimendi), freeing it from erroneous root-derivation from kuer- 'cut' and a habitual rendering as 'mutilate'; his meaning 'intimidation' is cogent, although he did not derive it from kurkura- (leaving the latter [possibly as 'clew'] apart and unintegrated). Molina: derived of kurkura- (c.) ‘scarecrow’ (moreover, there is also a double reduplication kurkurakurkurai-!). Tischler (HEG K:652): kurkura- <-- kuer-/kur- 'cut', but Guterbok, and later Puhvel called it erroneus.

semantic derivation: earthquake → shaking, tremor → fear
PA_root: katta- (Hitt.) + reduplication in the meaning of shaking of soil
comments: Puhvel (135): katkattiya- is a quasi-phonesthetic reduplicate (miming the rattling and rumbling of an earthquake?), similar to e.g. tastasiya- 'whisper', ku(a)sku(a)s- 'squash', or Gk. [tappaipco 'glimmer',.lat - tftillo 'tickle'. A derivation from katta 'down' (like e.g. appai-be finished' from appa) started with the incorrect rendering of katkattinu- as 'sink, dunk' (H. A. Potratz, Das Pferd in der Friihzeit 199 [1938]) and is now far fetched (though persistent: e.g. Friedrich. JCS 1:278-80 [1947]; Laroche, BSL 52:78 [1956]; Kammenhuber, Hippologia 45-6; Kronasser, Etym. 1:493; Oettinger, Stammhildung 346-7; G. Dunkel, KZ 95:221 - 3 [1981]).N.A.Mkrtcyan (Acta Antiqua 22:319 [1974]) adduced Arm.(katr)kat'el 'drip' (cf. the similar comparison, ibid. 318, of Arm.kosfkocjel- 'smash' with Hitt. kufajskufajs- 'squash'). If there is more than chance onomatopoeic similitude, perhaps the Hittite-Mitannian hippological usage of katkattiya- as 'shake off water' affected the Armenian meaning. There may also have been a semantic tie between demonic dripping and seismic convulsing in the Caucasus area and beyond (cf. the Amirani : [Norse] Loki parallel in Puhvel, Comparative Mythology 217 [1987]).

semantic derivation: joy, happiness → amusement, entertainment
hitt: dušk- / tusk-/tuskiya- 'be happy; enjoy; rejoice; amuse, entertain’'
comments: Ivanov (180), Kloekhorst (901): It is difficult to establish what the original stem of this verb is. E.g. Oettinger (1979a: 326) interprets the verb as tuške/a-zi (probably inspired by his etymology, <*tus-se/o-). In my view, 1sg.pret.act. tuškun and duškun prove that the stem cannot have been tuške/a-, as we then would expect **tuškenun. These forms seem to point to tušk-zi only. The forms 2sg.pres.act. duškatti and dušgatti then perhaps denote /tuskti/. The derivative dušganu- can hardly be seen as belonging to a stem tuške/a-: it is likely to stand for /tusknu-/. The 3sg.pres.act. du-uš-KI-IZ-zi, which in principle can be interpreted as du-uš-ke-ez-zi = /tuskets i/ as from a stem tuške/a-, can be read du-uš-ki-ez-zi = /tuskiets i/ as well, as from a stem tuškie/a-zi. When we assume that the stem was tušk-zi with a variant tuškie/a-zi, we perhaps can interpret the stem tuškara- seen in the derivatives tuškaratt-, tuškartar and tuškaraant- as /tuskra-/. Note that Rieken (1999a: 116-7) interprets these words as /tuskra-/ as well, although this is in conflict with her view that the verb is tuške/a-zi. She therefore states that “es sich wahrscheinlich um eine Reimbildung zu *našara- [handelt], da -ra- nicht an thematischen Verben tritt”. The root tušk- can only reflect a preform *TusK-. All proposed etmologies,however, presuppose that tušk- is a -ške/o-derived stem. Petersen (1937: 211, widely followed, e.g. by Oettinger l.c., Rieken l.c.) connected the verb with Skt. túsyati ‘to be satisfied’ and reconstructed *tus-se/o-. Neumann apud Tischler (HEG T: 466) connects the verb with ON þýðr ‘friendly’, Goth. þiuþ ‘das Gute’, which reflect a root *teu- ‘in freundlichem Sinne die Aufmerksamkeit zuwenden’. In my view, these proposals cannot be correct. The verb tušk-zi rather reflects a root *TusK-, which is comparable in structure to e.g. *mesg-, *resg- and *tres- in LIV2 Unfortunately I have been unable to find cognates. Molina Its derivatives are: tuškari-, tuškaratt- (c.) ‘happiness, entertainment’, dušganu- ‘to make happy’,duškaratar / duškarann- (n.)/ dušgariiyatar / dušgariyann- (n.) ‘happiness’, dušgarauwant- ‘happy, glad’. It is unfortunate that there are no obvious cognates for this lexeme, Tischler’s suggestion (HEG T: 466) about the connection of *tusk- with ONorv. þýðr ‘friendly’, Goth. þiuþ ‘goods’, which reflect PIE *teu-, has been refuted on the basis of that the verb tuškzi should correlate with the PIE *tusk-, and, overall, there are no grounds for disagreeing with this opinion. See. https://unora.unior.it/bitstream/11574/247522/1/Cammarosano_2014_Rejoicing_in_the_Gods.pdf

The formal and syntactic similarity between kantoru and qištoridν suggests a segmentation into qiš- + toridν. The second element of this reconstructed compound (i.e. Lyd. tro-(d)) apparently represents a lexical cognate of Luw. /trawi-(ti)/ ‘to pass, hand over’. Rather than comparing this element with the relative pronoun, as does Carruba, one attempt to reconstruct the element qišr- with the approximate meaning ‘thriving’. Then the denominative qišre- could originally mean ‘to cause to be thriving’, while the compound qišr-tori- > qištori- would have the literal meaning “to hand over in a thriving state”. Likewise, the highly tempting inner-Anatolian connection between Lyc. A mlu- and Luw. malwan- (and HLuw. ma-lu-wa/i) is weakened by the lack of a solid semantic assignment. Melchert (DLL:40f.) hesitantly suggests the meaning ‘tend to, care for’. On exclusively formal grounds, a connection of mlu- with the PIE root *mleu̯h2- (verbum dicendi) seems possible, but difficult to prove. Hence this could be a development from ‘to speak’ > ‘to care for’ or ‘to take care of’. The word km̃mẽti ‘how(ever) many’ could serve as a subject and tddẽta ‘nourishing, food (?)’ as a direct object. Thus, the meaning ‘to take care of (the food)’ in the sense of distributing it to the army could be adopted. "se=i=(ẽ)nẽ telẽzijẽ tddẽta mluñte w[..]qrai[j]e km̃mẽti" -- ‘And however many took care of the food(?) of the armies… (vel sim.)’. The word ẽnẽ ‘under’ may function as a preverb modifying the semantics of mlu- slightly, cf. ẽnẽ sm̃mate in TL 44b.12 (Sasseville 2021a:52). comments: PAna *u̯ósu-/u̯ésu- ‘good’; PAna *u̯és-o/to- ‘to be pleasant, favored’; according to LIV2+ s.v., the basic meaning of PIE *h1u̯es- is ‘to become/be good’. Kloekhorst (1018): In the vocabulary KBo 1.42 iv 42, ú-iz-za pa-a-an glosses Akk. LA-BI-RU ‘old’, showing a clear word space between izza and pn. On the basis of this attestation, Güterbock (1955: 64f.) suggested that the word is a univerbation of itt- ‘year’ (q.v.) and pnt- ‘having gone’ (see pai-zi / pai-) and that it originally meant ‘the year hasgone’. Rieken (1999: 26) states that therefore e/izza must be interpreted as the original nom.sg. of itt- ‘year’. This interpretation is unlikely in my view, however, since an interjection of a loose sentence ‘the year has gone’ is quite ungrammatical. Moreover I cannot envisage how such an interjection would develop into an inflecting adjective. It therefore might be better to interpret *e/izza as gen.sg., univerbated with a *pnt- that agrees with the noun it determines, so that uizza pnt- originally meant ‘having gone with regard to the year(s)’, which developed into ‘having gone weary’. See for further etymology the separate lemmata itt- ‘year’ and pai-zi / pai- ‘to go’. Another question is whether PIE *h1u̯o/es-u- adj. ‘good’ can be related to the u̯-less adjective PIE *h1(E)s-u- ‘good’ (NIL:239–243), cf., e.g., Hitt. āššu- adj./sbst. ‘good’ and the compound member Ved. su- = Gk. εὐ- < PIE *h1s-u-. Subsequently, a new full-grade form *h1Es-u- was formed to dissimilated *h1s-u- (NIL:255 n. 3 with lit.). Others, however, propose to connect the stem *h1(E)s-u- with the PIE root *h1es- ‘to be (there)’ (cf. NIL:239 n. 1), which would then preclude a connection with PIE *h1u̯es-.

comments: PIE u-stem adjective *h1ē̆su-, *h1e(h1)su- vel sim. means ‘good’. Puhvel (204): assu- has been traditionally connected (ever since Friedrich, /f 41:370-2 [1923]) with Gk. 'good, brave, noble', eis 'well', gen. pi. (Homeric) 'good things' (IE *[e]su~ from *es-ibc\ like e.g. Skt. sdnt- 'being; real, true, good', or Gk. 'goods, possessions' with its probable Lycian caique ahntai on the Xanthos trilingual [Lye. 17]; cf. Laroche, Fouilles de Xanthos 6:58, 68 [1979]; already Hrozny, Heth. KB 103, adduced the comparison of Akk. busu 'goods' with basil 'be'), besides IE *esu- 'good' in other branches of Anatolian (Palaic, Luwian, Hier. wasu- 'good; well-being'), somewhat like Skt. su 'well' besides 'good; wealth' (cf. e.g. Mayrhofer, KEWA 3: 173-4; Kammenhuber, KZ 77:169-70 [1961]). The verbal form assari has been explained as denominative from assu-, analogous to the gloss-wedged Luwoid wassari(q.v. s.v. was[s]-) from Luw. wasu- (cf. Oettinger, MSS 34:136 [1976]), and assiya- has been similarly accounted for (cf. e.g. Kronasser, VLFH41; Neu, Interpretation 20). Alternatively, assiya- has been kept apart from assu- and connected (as reflecting *ans-y -or *ns-y-) with IE *ans- (IEW41) seen in Goth, ansts 'favor, grace', ON ast 'favor, love', ON unna, OE OS OHG unnan 'favor, be ungrudging' (cf. G. Jucquois, RHA 22:89-91 [1964]; Gusmani, Lessico 72). Yet the inner-Hittite data cast doubt on the derivation of assu- from IE *(e)su-; a derivational tie to the verb 'to be' ought to be still palpable in Hittite, and the near universal geminated spelling assu- (vs. constant asanzi, asant-) is difficult to justify (cf. e.g. KUB XXXIII 109 I 5 asanza memias 'the? matter [is] true'). A chain of semantic developments 'being' > 'real' > 'true' > 'good' > 'dear', while not impossible, would be unique (Gk. in the direction of 'brave, noble'). Furthermore, assu- does not basically denote that which is intrinsically and objectively good (as does inherently IE *[e].?w-) but rather that which is found to be agreeable; hence DUG.GA 'good' does not cover assu- but rather lazz(a)i- 'good, sound'. It is therefore advisable to start with the sense 'favored, dear'; for the sequence 'favored, dear'>'good'>'goods' one need but compare Lat. bonus <*duenos, lit. 'favored'; cf. bea-<*d\veya- 'favor, make happy', Vedic diivas-, duvoya 'favor', duvasyati 'show favor, honor'). Therefore the root ass- can be considered basic, with assiya- a primary verbal derivative like e.g. arsiya- beside arsor parkiya- beside park- (cf. also Carruba, Oriens Antiquus 13:150 [1974]). assu- is a w-stem derivative from ass- .aw-, assu- point to a reconstruction *cms- or *ns-, if we compare e.g. dassu-<*donsu- or *dnsu-, or hassu-<*Hyonsu-, with *ns>ss rather than nz (cf. Kronasser, VLFH 73; Oettinger, Eide 24). Accordingly A.W- can be connected immediately with IE *crns-, *rrs- 'favor' which Jucquois proposed as the etymon of assiya- (see above). IE *ans- thus has a rich progeny in Hittite but little in other Anatolian; on the other hand Hittite (unlike most of Anato lian) has little trace of IE *wes~ and does not (unlike Hierogly phic) form a causative of es- 'sit'; of IE *(e)su- there are no Anatolian traces at all. Cf. Puhvel, KZ 94;65-70 (1980). O. Szemerenyi's derivation from Hitt. *ass(u)yapiya- 'health-giver' (Journal of Hellenic Studies 94:155 [1974]) richly deserves rejection. Szemerenyi (Kratylos 11:215-8 [1966]) also questionably interpreted e.g. ishassara- 'lady' (q.v. s.v. isha-) as *isha-assara- and isolated an *asar which he compared either with Gk. ooip 'wife' (as *osr) or with assiya- 'be dear' (as *nser oved one,<*tlove, affection'). /azza-/ is part of a formula frequently found in comparable phrasings in the other Anatolian and neighbouring languages: ‘beloved by god X’. Melchert 2016b:242 states that the HLuw. /massanadi azzammi-/ is semantically equivalent to the Hitt. expression šiunit kaneššant- ‘favoured by the gods’.

comments: Puhvel (173): Luw. nom. pl. c. mi-i-ya-wi-en-zi (KUB XXXV 133 I11 5 [Starke, KLTU 281, Stammbildung 3581); cf. KBo XXII 254 Vs. 10 ]mi-ya-ti-wa-an-zi[ ? miu- (< *miH2u-) is cognate with Lat. mitis, OIr. mdith 'soft. mild', OIr. min 'smooth', Lith. mylas 'tender, lovely' (IE W 71 1-2). This precise tie-in (first in J. Knobloch, Kratylos 4:38 [1959]) was obfuscated (e. g. Oettinger, Stammbildung 47 1 ; Weitenberg, Stamme (122-3, 421-2) by mixing in mai-lmiya- 'grow, mature, be born', where homophony and semantics have wrought confusion, but which has an entirely different root etymology. Cf. tni(e)ura-, miumiu-. Korkhorst (584): Anat. cognates: CLuw. mu- / ma- (adj.) ‘smooth’ (nom.pl.c. mi-i-a-i5-en-zi). IE cognates: Lat. mtis ‘soft’, Lith. míelas ‘tender, lovely’, Russ. mílyj ‘sweet’, etc PIE *míh1-(e)u-. See CHD L-N: 306f. for attestations of mu-, 243f. for mšš-zi, 309 for mumar, and 291 for mnu-zi. Note that CHD regards the forms spelled as mi-e-nu- as belonging to the group of mu- as well, but this is not obligatory (see s.v. mienu-zi). I will therefore disregard these forms here. Note that CHD incorrectly cites nom.sg.c. “mi-u-uš” (KUB 39.41 obv. 17 (NS), KUB 33.38 iv 10 (OH/MS)), which in fact must be mi-ú-uš. It is clear that we are dealing with an ablauting u-stem adjective mu- /ma-, with derivatives mnu-zi (like tepnu-zi of tpu- / tpa- ‘few, little’), mšš-zi (fientive in -šš- of the root m-, which contrasts with e.g. tepašš-zi of tpu- and idalašš-zi of idlu- /idla- ‘bad, evil’, but matches parkšš-zi beside parkušš-zi of parku- /parka- ‘high’) and mumar (a derivative in -ar /-n- of the stem mu-, showing the development *-u- > -um-). Etymologically, mu- has to be compared with Lat. mtis ‘soft’, Lith. míelas ‘tender, lovely’, etc. (thus first Knobloch 1959: 38), which point to a root *meih1- (cf. Schrijver 1991: 240). We therefore have to reconstruct *méih1-u- / *mih1-éu-, which was levelled out to *míh1-u- / *míh1-eu- and regularly yielded OH /míu-/, /míau-/ > NH /mu-/, /mau-/, spelled mi-i-u°, mi-i-a-u°. Klorkhorst 579 mienu-zi (Ib2) ‘?’: 3pl.pret.act. mi-e-nu-er (KBo 14.42 obv. 11 (NH)), mi-e-nu- u-e-er (KUB 19.22, 3 (NH)), 3sg.imp.act. mi-e-nu-ud-du (KUB 17.12 ii 14 (NS)). Often, these words are regarded identical with mnu-zi ‘to soften’ (see s.v. mu-) (cf. CHD L-N: 242, Puhvel HED 6: 171). This is a bit awkward, as all attestations of which a meaning ‘to soften’ is clear are spelled mi-i-nu- and mi-nu-, but not **mi-e-nu-, whereas for all forms that are spelled mi-e-nu- a translation ‘to soften’ or ‘soft’ is not obligatory. For the forms mienuer and mienuer cf. CHD L-N: 291, for mienuddu, mienuš and mienu cf. CHD L-N: 242. A nominal mienu- is found in gen.sg. mi-e-nu-a-aš (KUB 33.103 iii 7), but the connection with the verb mienu-zi and the adj. mienu- is unclear. Note however that due to the lowering of OH /i/ to NH /e/ before -n- as described in § 1.4.8.1d, the attestations mi-e-nu- formally could be regarded as the NH outcomes of original mnu-zi. semantic derivation: internal body part (spleen) → seat of emotions → kindness
IE_cognates: Skt. jani ‘to procreate, Lat. ntus ‘born’, etc.; for the meaning ‘kindness’, cf. Lat. gentilis ‘gentle
comments: Klorkhorst (468) Derivatives: genzue/a-zi, genzuae-zi (Ic1 / Ic2) ‘to treat gently, to be compassionate (towards), to be kind (to)’ PIE * ĝenh1-su- See Puhvel HED 4: 154f. for attestations. The word denotes a body part, which can be identified with the lower abdomen on the basis of its place in lists of body parts. Besides its literal meaning, it also occurs metaphorically in expressions like genzu d- i / d- ‘to take pity on’, genzu ar(k)-zi ‘to have fondness for’, genzu pai-i / pi- ‘to extend kindness’, but also in its derivatives genzuae-zi ‘to be gentle with’ and genzuala- ‘kindhearted’. The literal meaning ‘lower abdomen’ (‘*area of the loins’?) and the metaphoric meaning ‘kindness’ seem to fit the PIE root *enh1- ‘to beget, to procreate’ (Skt. jani - ‘to procreate, Gr. #‘to come into being’, Lat. ntus ‘born’, etc.; for the meaning ‘kindness’, cf. Lat. gentilis ‘gentle’, ModEng. kind). It is quite generally assumed that genzu- reflects * ĝenh1-su- (cf. Skt. rá+su-enjoyable’, dháku- ‘burning’, but also Hitt. tepšu- < *dhebh-su-), but details are unclear. The biggest question is how the cluster -nz- came about, especially in comparison to the fact that *VnsV > Hitt. VššV. For instance, Eichner (1973a: 55, 86) assumes that in * ĝenh1-su- the laryngeal was vocalized to *genasu- and that this vocalized laryngeal only got syncopated after the assimilation of *-ns- to -šš-. The secondary cluster *-ns- then yielded -nz-. It is problematic, however, that neither vocalization of laryngeals (cf. Melchert 1994a: 65) nor syncope of vowels is a regular phonetic development in Hittite. Rieken (1999a: 220-1) remarks that Skt. dhák u- is remodelled after an o-stem, while rá+su- goes back to an IE s-stem *rém-e/os- (although opinions differ on this, cf. Mayrhofer 1986-2002: 2.428). In the same way genzu- then could be derived from the s-stem * ĝénh1-e/os- (Gr. , Lat. genus). According to Rieken, “[d]ie Bewahrung des Nasals vor dem Sibilanten und die Epenthese van t in genzu-, die der normalen Entwicklung widersprechen, erklären sich aus dem Bedürfnis, die Morphemgrenzen deutlich zu bewahren”. This is rather ad hoc, however. In my view, the solution is quite simple: just as *-ms- and *-mh1s- behaved differently when in intervocalic position (*VmsV > VššV (*h2emsu-> aššu-) whereas *Vmh1sV > VnšV (*h2ómh1sei > nši)), so did -ns- and -nh1s- as well. The first one assimilated to -šš-, whereas *Vnh1sV yielded VnzV (for this reflex compare *CnsV > CanzV and *CmsV > CanzV). The preservation of -e- is quite remarkable. Apparently, genzu- < *enh1su- did not participate in the sound law *eRCC > aRCC, nor in the sound law *enT > anT. This points to the following relative chronology: (1) *enT > anT; (2) *Vnh1sV >VnzV; (3) *eRCC > aRCC. Molina: Concerning Hitt. genzu-/ginzu-, we can rely on the work of S.Kimball (2011), who provides analysis of semantics, form and correspondences, compares contexts, including enumerations of body parts with this lexeme, and convincingly demonstrates that genzu- , most likely, originally meant not the knees or genitals, as suggested, in particular, by J.Puhvel (HED K: 154-157), but the spleen, which in other Indo-European languages also becomes the source of emotions (Gk. σπλήν > Eng. spleen). Since Kimball manages to identify a series of names of internal body parts in which genzu- is clearly opposed to innards(karāt-), ‘live’ (UZU NIG.GIG), ‘kidneys’ (UZU KALAM), ‘abdominal cavity’ (KARŠU), ‘genitals’ (UZU ÙR), and ‘heart’ (ker-), the identification of this internal source of kindness appears justified (Kimball 2011:6). The metaphorical transition internal body part (spleen) > kindnessfrom a typological point of view is quite trivial:Derivatives of genzu-genzuwazi to treat gently, to be compassionate genzuwala- kind- hearted. The etymology in the literature varies between two versions: A. *gem-s-/gen-s- with the meaning to squeeze’ (Laroche 1965), B. *genh to give birth, to nurture (Rieken 1999, EDHIL).

IE_cognates: Gk. χαίρω ‘I rejoice’ is to χάρις OR χαρά ‘grace/joy’, Ved. hā́ryati ‘finds pleasure, delights, likes’, Av. zara- ‘aim, goal(?), Lat. horior ‘to urge on’; OHG ger ‘desirous’, gerōn ‘to desire’
comments: PIE *ĝher-/*ĝhor-/*ĝhr-. Kloekhorst (449): IE cognates: Skt. háryati ‘to desire, to covet’, Gr. *# ‘to rejoice at, to take pleasure in’. PIE *ĝhr-e/o- See Puhvel HED 4: 80-1 for attestations. The verb and its derivatives are predominantly attested in NH texts. Puhvel (l.c.) connects the words to the IE root *her- as reflected in Skt. háryati ‘to desire, to covet’, Av. zara- ‘aim, goal(?)’, Gr. *# ‘to rejoice at, to take pleasure in’, * ‘grace, favour’, but also in Lat. horior ‘to incite, to urge on’. The word kari would then be similar to Gr. *‘grace, favour’ and reflect a petrified dative-locative. taking kar-i from the reduced grade *ĝhr-, as Gk. χάρις? The denominative + kariia- (³) (middle) is at least functionally related to *kar- (perhaps actually to kari as a hypostasis) in much the same way as Gk. χαίρω ‘I rejoice’ is to χάρις/χαρά ‘grace/joy’; formally it corresponds rather to the likewise full-grade Vedic hā́ryati ‘finds pleasure, delights, likes’. Lat. horior ‘to urge on’; OHG ger ‘desirous’, gerōn ‘to desire’, etc. (PIE *ĝher-/*ĝhor-). Formally, the closest match would be an o-colored full grade as in Avestan zara- ‘striving, aim, favor’ (*ĝhor-o-). For PA, if palatovelars were distinct, PA *ĝhor-/*ĝor- > *kar-.

semantic derivation: express praise or blame → shame
IE_cognates: NPhryg. (-)τετικμενος; PGmc. *teihan ‘to accuse’
comments: Nikolaev (2023): compares Hittite tekri- ‘derogation, condemnation’ < *do/ei̯ḱ-ri- with NPhryg. (-)τετικμενος and argues in favor of a translation ‘condemned’ and derivation from PIE *dei̯ḱ- (Ved. diś-, Gk. δείκνυμι, Lat. dīcere). The third piece of evidence for the root *dei̯ḱ- used to express the idea of censure comes from PGmc. *teihan ‘to accuse’. The source of the semantics is sought in Indo-European poetic language; it is argued that the PIE root *dei̯ḱ- could be employed in verbal contexts related not just to praise (Nikolaev 2012), but also to blame.

semantic derivation: to cover oneself → to feel shame
IE_cognates: OE sc(e)amu ‘shame; disgrace’, OHG scama, German Scham, English shame
translation: to be disgraced, to feel shame
hitt: zammurāi-, (GK)zammurai- (n.), (GK)zammuratt(i)- (c.), zammurinu- 'to cause to be humiliated'
comments: Nikolaev (2019): In Hittite texts zammurāi- and its verbal nouns, „zammurai- (n.) and zammuratt(i)- (c.), denote offence of the gravest kind: the objects are usually gods, kings, cities, and lands. In most of its occurrences the verb refers to verbal insult, slander, or defamation. “Indictment of Madduwatta” (CTH 147), where zammurāizzi is used along with idālun memian and kūruraš memian memai. Similarly, zammurāizzi is preceded by idālu uttar in Tudḫaliya II’s instructions to the army “speaks evil/hostile word(s)”. The verb zammurāi- can refer not only to a verbal insult, but also to actions constituting an offence. For instance, in a letter sent by the future emperor Tudḫaliya IV? to the queen Puduḫepa? the speaker uses the verb zammurāi-, speaking about the distress he caused to the emperor (presumably Ḫattušili III). zammurāi is also used to denote defilement and profanation. In a passage from “Instructions for Temple Personnel,” shepherds are made to swear that they will deliver first-born animals to the temple, rather than keep some of the cattle for themselves, which would amount to desecration and offense. Comparing to hatganuzi 'stresses out', which interchanges with zammurai in some contexts, we can return to the translation ‘belittles, causes to be disgraced'. It appears that defamation and disgrace are two important connotations of the verb zammurāi- and its derivatives. At the same time, there does not seem to be sufficient textual evidence for the meaning ‘to attack, assail’. Luw. verb (*)zammurā- ‘insult’ (Kronasser 1966:482, Kloekhorst 2008:1030): 'insult, slander’. An alternative analysis of Nikolaev's of Luv. (*)zammurās being a denominative verb based on an athematic verbal noun *zammur ( < *zammuwar with syncope); in this case (*)zammurā- would be comparable, e.g., to Hitt. kururāi- (KBo 9.96 i 9ʹ) ‘to be hostile’, based on kurur ‘hostility’. Potential cognates in Anatolian languages: one such cognate was identified by Neumann (1969: 396) in Lyc. zum̃me˜, zum̃mã ‘harm?’ (Nikolaev suggests 'desecration, violation (of a religiously significant object/place)'). As far as our limited knowledge of Lycian historical phonology allows us to tell, initial z- in Lycian goes back to Proto-Luvic *ts1- (< PIE *t̯i-, *g/g̑(h)̯i-) and *ts2 ( <*ts- / *ds-). But Nikolaev (2019:191) rejects this etymology on formal grounds: "Based on the known sound laws one may propose a Transponat *(s)k̑em-: both the a-vowel and the geminate -mm- of Luvian (*)zammurā- would be regular by Čop’s Law (*tsem- > *tsamm-), while the initial affricate can be viewed as a product of palatalization of *k̑ by the following *e. For these phonological developments one may compare CLuv. zalla- ‘to trot’, HLuv. zallal- ‘vehicle’ going back to IE *(s)k̑el- (cf. Lith. šúolis ‘a leap’). He suggests English shame going back to *skamō f. (OE sc(e)amu ‘shame; disgrace’, OHG scama, German Scham). These words have no standard Indo-European etymology and their derivation from a verbal root *(s)k̑em- ‘to be disgraced, to feel shame’, posited on the strength of Anatolian data, appears semantically and formally compelling.
